title-group.article-title: Cucurbitane-type triterpenoids from the vines of Momordica charantia and their anti-inflammatory, cytotoxic, and antidiabetic activity

sec.title: Orphanage
sec.p:
Cucurbitane-type triterpenoids from the vines of
Momordica charantia
and their anti-inflammatory, cytotoxic, and antidiabetic activity

sec.title: Orphanage
sec.p:
Chia-Ching Liaw a, b , Hung-Tse Huang a, c , Hui-Kang Liu a , Yu-Chi Lin a, d , Li-Jie Zhang a ,
Wen-Chi Wei a , Chien-Chang Shen a , Chia-Lun Wu a, e , Chung-Yi Huang e, ** , Yao-Haur Kuo
a, f, *

sec.title: Orphanage
sec.p: ARTICLE INFO

sec.title: Keywords:
sec.p: Cucurbitane-type triterpenoids
Kuguaovins
Cytotoxicity
Anti-inflammatory activity
GLP-1 secretion
ABSTRACT

Phytochemical investigation of the ethanol extract from wild
Momordica charantia
vines has resulted in isolation of seven cucurbitane-type triterpenoids, including six undescribed compounds, kuguaovins H‒M, and the known compound, momordicoside K. The structures of the isolated compounds were elucidated on the basis of spectroscopic analyses, including 1D and 2D NMR, and MS experiments. The chemical structure of momordicoside K was determined for the first time by X-ray crystallographic analysis and its absolute configuration assigned. The cytotoxicity against four human tumor cell lines and anti-inflammatory activities on LPS-stimulated RAW264.7 macrophages were evaluated. Of the isolates, kaguaovin L exhibited potential cytotoxicity against MCF-7, HEp-2, Hep-G2, and WiDr cancer cell lines and showed moderate anti-NO production activity. In addition, kuguaovins H and J also showed the stimulatory effect of GLP-1 secretion on the murine intestinal secretin tumor cell line (STC-1).

sec.title: 1. Introduction
sec.p:
In our continuing search for potential components from the bioactive fractions of wild
M. charantia
, six undescribed cucurbitane-type triterpene derivatives ( 1–6 ), together with a known derivative, momordicoside K ( 7 ) (Murakami et al.,), were isolated and characterized ( Fig. 1 ). Structural elucidations of the undescribed isolates were based on detailed spectral analyses, including 2D NMR experiments ( 1 H– 1 H COSY, HSQC, HMBC and NOESY) and spectroscopic comparison with related compounds. In addition, the absolute configuration of compound 7 was determined by X-ray crystallographic analysis.

sec.title: 2.1. Identification of the isolated compounds from the vine of M. charantia
sec.p: a Recorded at 125 MHz in pyridine- d .
5 b Recorded at 150 MHz in pyridine- d .

Based on the characteristic NOESY correlations of compound 1 ( Fig. 2B ), major cross-peaks of H-3/Me-28 and Me-29, H-9/Me-29 and Me-30, H-17/Me-30, and H-8/Me-18 and OMe-19 were observed. According to the biosynthetic pathway of cucurbitane-type triterpenes, together with the first reported crystallographic structure of momordicoside K ( 7 ) ( Fig. 3 ), H-3 and H-17 should be in the α- orientation, while H-8 should be in the β -orientation. However, the stereochemistry of C-19 and C-23 was determined as R configuration by comparison with 1 H and 13 C-NMR chemical shifts of taikuguasin D. Finally, the complete structure of compound 1 was established as 3 β -O -(3-methoxy-3-oxopropanoyl)-5 β ,19 R -epoxy-19-methoxycucurbita-6,24-dien-3,23-diol 23 R -O - β -D-glucopyranoside, and the compound was named kaguaovin H.

Compound 2 had the same molecular formula deduced from m/z 771.4284 ([M+Na] + , calcd. for C 41 H 64 O 12 Na, 771.4295) in the HRESIMS experiment and IR absorptions at 3399, 1754, 1728, 1640, and 1446 cm 1 as those of compound 1 . The 1 H and 13 C-NMR spectra data ( Tables 1 and 2 ) of both 1 and 2 were very similar, suggesting that 2 is an analog of 1 . However, the proton signals of H-8 ( δ H 2.29) and H-19 ( δ H 4.54) in the 1 H-NMR spectrum and the carbon signals of C-8 ( δ C 49.7) and C-19 ( δ C 114.1) in the 13 C-NMR spectrum were different from those of 2 . According to our previous study on the stereochemistry of cucurbitane-type triterpenoids, together with the evidence of NOESY correlation between H-19 and H-8 ( Fig. 2B ), the C-19 configuration of compound 2 should be S (
). Thus, compound 2 was a C-19 epimer of 1 and named kaguaovin I (3 β -O -(3-methoxy-3-oxopropanoyl)-5 β ,19 S -epoxy-19-methoxycucurbita-6,24-dien-3,23-diol-23 R -O -β -D-glucopyranoside).

Compound 3 displayed a sodiated quasimoleclar ion peak at m/z 685.4283 [M+Na] + in the HRESIMS experiment, consistent with the molecular formula of C 38 H 62 O 9 Na. Its IR spectrum exhibited hydroxyl ( 3444 cm 1 ) and olefinic (1642 and 1454 cm 1 ) functional groups. The 1 H-NMR spectrum ( Table 2 ) of compound 3 showed signals for six singlet methyls ( δ H 0.85, 0.88, 0.91, 1.37, 1.67, and 1.76), one doublet methyl [ δ H 1.18 (d, J = 6.0 Hz)], one triplet methyl [1.09 (t, J = 8.4 Hz)], eight oxymethine protons [ δ H 3.55 (br d, J =11.4 Hz), 3.89, 4.03, 4.21, 4.22, 4.86, 4.92 (td, J =4.2, 10.8 Hz), and 4.96 (d, J =8.4 Hz)], and three olefinic protons [ δ H 5.62 (br d, J =9.0 Hz), 5.64 (dd, J =3.6, 9.6 Hz), and 6.08 (dd, J = 1.2, 9.6 Hz)]. The 13 C-NMR ( Table 1 ) and DEPT spectra displayed 38 signals, including six quaternary carbons, fifteen methine carbons, nine methylene carbons, and eight methyl carbons. Detailed comparison of the 1 H and 13 C-NMR data with compounds 3 and 1 revealed that both had a structure similar to the 5,19- epoxycucurbitane-type triterpene skeleton with a glucose moiety except for the absence of a malonyl group and the methyl groups in 3 . Additionally, the signals of δ H 3.39 (m), 3.78 (m) and 1.09 (t, J =8.4 Hz) and δ C 65.9 and 15.5 were found in 3 , the characteristic of an ethoxyl group that was located at C-19 and confirmed by the HMBC correlation ( Fig. 2A ) between H-19 ( δ H 4.54) and 19- CH 2 CH 3 ( δ C 65.9). The chemical structure and stereochemistry of 3 were further confirmed by 1 H– 1 H COSY, HSQC, and HMBC correlations, together with its NOESY correlations similar to 1 . Thus, the structure of 3 was identified as 5 β ,19 R -epoxy-19-ethoxycucurbita-6,24-dien-3β,23-diol 23 R -O -β- D-glucopyranoside and named kaguaovin J.
a Recorded at 500 MHz in pyridine- d .
5 b Recorded at 600 MHz in pyridine- d .
5 c Overlapped.

Compound 4 was obtained as a white amorphous powder, and its molecular formula was determined to be C 40 H 62 O 10 by a quasimolecular ion peak at m/z 725.4228 [M+Na] + in the HRESIMS experiment. The IR spectrum showed the presence of hydroxyl ( 3412 cm 1 ), carbonyl ( 1716 cm 1 ), and olefinic (1655 and 1442 cm 1 ) groups. The 1 H-, 13 C-, DEPT, and HSQC NMR spectra ( Tables 1 and 2 ) showed the characteristic signals of a cucurbita-5,24-dien-3,7,23-triol-19-al triterpene skeleton with a sugar moiety, including aldehyde groups [ δ C 207.3, δ H 10.57 (s), C-19], a trisubstituted olefinic group [ δ C 144.1, C-5; δ C 124.6, δ H 6.19 (br d, J =5.0 Hz), C-6], dimethyl trisubstituted olefinic group [ δ C 129.1, δ H 5.61 (br d, J =9.0 Hz), C-24; δ C 132.3, C-25; δ C 18.2, δ H 1.74 (s), C-26; δ C 25.8, δ H 1.67 (s), C-27], four other singlet methyls [ δ H 0.88 × 2, 1.13, and 1.23; δ C 14.9, 26.9, 18.1, 25.1 for C-18, C-29, C-30, C-28, respectively], one doublet methyl [ δ H 1.18, (d, J =6.5 Hz), δ C 18.9, C-21], three oxymethines [ δ H 5.08, δ C 78.0, C-3; δ H 4.32, δ C 65.4, C-7; δ H 4.92, δ C 75.3, C-23], and a glucose moiety [ δ H 4.95 (d, J = 8.0 Hz), δ C 104.0, Glc-1; δ H 4.00, δ C 75.6, Glc-2; δ H 3.88, δ C 78.3, Glc-3; δ H 4.2, δ C 71.8, Glc-4; δ H 4.21, δ C 78.9, Glc-5; δ H 4.46 (br d, J =11.5 Hz), 4.34 (m), δ C 62.9, Glc-6]. In the HMBC spectrum ( Fig. 2A ), the correlation between Glc-1 and C-23 suggested that the glucose group was attached at C-23. By comparison with the previous literature and acid hydrolysis of compound 4 , glucose was identified as β -D-glucose. In addition, the COSY correlations of H-2’ [ δ H 5.77 (dd, J =1.5, 15.0 Hz)]/ H-3 [ δ H 6.99 (dq, J =15.0, 7.0 Hz)]/H-4’ [ δ H 1.58 (dd, J =1.5, 7.0 Hz)] and HMBC correlation between the protons of olefinic groups (H-2 ′ and H-3 ′ ) and a carbonyl ( δ C 165.7, C-1 ′ ) indicated the presence of a ( E )-2- butenoic ester group. Furthermore, the HMBC correlations of H-3 and C-1 ′ were observed to assign the ( E )-2-butenoic ester at C-3. The stereochemistry of compound 4 was determined by NOESY experiments and comparison with previously isolated cucurbitanes. The NOESY spectrum ( Fig. 2B ) of 5 exhibited major correlations of H-3/Me-28 and Me 29, H-9/Me-29 and Me-30, H-17/Me-30, and H-8/Me-18 and CHO-19, suggesting that compound 4 has the same configuration as 1 . According to the above evidence, compound 4 was identified as 3β- O -( E )-butenoyl-7 β -hydroycucurbita-5,24-dien-3,7,23-triol-19-al 23 R -O -β -D-glucopyranoside and named kaguaovin K.

Compound 5 , a white amorphous powder, had a molecular formula of C 38 H 62 O 10 from a sodiated quasimolecular ion peak [M+Na] + at m/z 701.4225 in the HRESIMS experiment. Its IR spectra displayed hydroxyl ( 3379 cm 1 ), carbonyl ( 1749 cm 1 ), and olefinic (1645 and 1462 cm 1 ) functional groups. The 13 C-NMR and DEPT spectra ( Table 1 ) of 5 exhibited 38 signals, containing a carbonyl ( δ C 175.7), four olefinic carbons ( δ C 120.0, 128.3, 137.7, 148.0), seven methyl carbons ( δ C 15.5, 17.8, 18.9, 26.0 × 2, 26.4, 28.2), two methoxy carbons ( δ C 50.1 and 55.8), and a sugar anomeric carbon ( δ C 96.5). The 1 H-NMR spectrum ( Table 2 ) apparently showed signals for six singlet methyls ( δ H 0.77, 1.00, 1.08,1.42, and 1.31 × 2), one doublet methyl [ δ H 1.18, (d, J =6.5 Hz)], two methoxy protons ( δ H 3.20 and 3.41), an anomeric proton [ δ H 6.07 (d, J =7.8 Hz)], and three olefinic protons [ δ H 5.54, (d, J =6.5 Hz); δ H 5.61 (ddd, J = 5.4, 8.4, 15.6 Hz); δ H 5.95, (m)]. The 1 H– 1 H COSY spectrum exhibited six fragments of correlations, H-10/H 2 -1/H 2 -2/H-3, H-6/H-7/H-8, H 2 -11/H 2 -12, H 2 -15/H 2 -16/H-17, Me-21/H-20/H 2 -22/ H-23/H-24, and Glc-1/Glc-2/Glc-3/Glc-4/Glc-5/Glc-6 ( Fig. 2A ). The HMBC correlations ( Fig. 2A ) of Me-28/C-29, C-3, C-4, C-5, H-7/C-5, C-6, H-8/C-6, C-7, C-9, C-11, C-19, H-10/C-9, C-19, Me-18/C-12, C-13, C-14, C-17, Me-30/C-8, C-13, C-14, C-15, Me-21/C-17, Me-27/C-24, and C-25 indicated that compound 5 possessed a 3,7,25-trihydroxycucurbita-5,23-dien-19-oic acid triterpene skeleton with a sugar moiety and two methoxy groups. The sugar was further identified as β- D-glucose by acid hydrolysis, and the coupling constant of Glc-1 ( J =7.8 Hz) and located on C-19 due to the HMBC correlation of Glc-1/C-19. In addition, two methoxy groups were assigned at C-7 and C-25 by the HMBC correlations of OMe ( δ H 3.41)/C-7 ( δ C 75.7) and OMe ( δ H 3.20)/C-25 ( δ C 74.8). The stereochemistry of compound 5 was determined by NOESY experiments and a detailed comparison with momordicoside K. Based on the above findings, compound 5 was unambiguously determined to be 3β-hydroxy-7 β ,25-dimethoxycucurbita-5,23-dien-19-oic acid 19- O -β -D-glucopyranoside and named kaguaovin L.

Due to a sodiated quasimoleclar ion peak at m/z 525.3562 [M+Na] + in the HRESIMS spectrum, compound 6 has a formula of C 31 H 50 O 5 . The 1 H-NMR spectrum ( Table 2 ) of 6 displayed five singlet methyl protons ( δ H 0.86 × 2, 1.53, 1.54, and 1.72), one doublet methyl proton [ δ H 0.95, (d, J = 6.0 Hz)], four olefinic protons [ δ H 5.63, (br d, J = 9.6 Hz); δ H 5.94, (m); δ H 5.95, (m); 6.19, (br d, J = 9.6 Hz)], and one methoxy protons ( δ H 3.36). The 13 C-NMR and DEPT spectra ( Table 1 ) showed 31 signals, including six methyl carbons ( δ C 14.9, 18.8, 19.3, 19.9, and 30.8 × 2), one methoxy carbon ( δ C 57.6), one oxymethylene carbon ( δ C 63.5), one oxymethine carbon ( δ C 71.8), one acetal carbon ( δ C 112.5), four olefinic carbons ( δ C 124.2, 132.3, 132.5, and 141.7), four methine carbons, two oxygenated quaternary carbons ( δ C 86.6 and 69.7), four quaternary carbons, and seven methylene carbons. The above observation indicated that compound 6 could be assigned as a 5,19-epoxycucurbitane-type triperpene with one methoxy group. The 1 H– 1 H COSY correlations ( Fig. 2A ) of H-10/H 2 -1/H 2 -2/H-3, H-6/H-7/H-8, H 2 -11/H 2 - 12, H 2 -15/H 2 -16/H-17, and Me-21/H-20/H 2 -22/H-23/H-24 and HMBC correlations ( Fig. 2 ) of Me-29/C-28, C-3, C-4, C-5, H 2 -28/C-3, C-4, C-5, C-29, H-7/C-5, C-6, H-8/C-6, C-7, H-19/C-5, C-8, C-9, C-10, C-11, Me-18/C-12, C-13, C-14, C-17, Me-30/C-8, C-13, C-14, C-15, Me-21/C-17, Me-26/C-24, C-25 established the structure of 6 to be 5,19-epoxy-19- methoxycucurbita-6,23-dien-3,25,28-triol. NOESY correlations ( Fig. 2B ) of H-10/Me-29, Me-30, Me-30/H-17, H-8/Me-18, and OMe were observed, indicating that H-10, H-17, Me-29, and Me-30 are α -configurations, whereas H-8, Me-18, and CH 2 OH-28 are β -configurations. In addition, the stereochemistry of C- 19 in 6 was determined as R by the NOESY correlation between OMe and H-8. According to the above findings, compound 6 was assigned as 5β,19-epoxy-19 R -methoxycucurbita-6,23( E )-dien-3,25,28-triol and named kaguaovin N.

The planar structure of 7 was also established by 2D NMR correlations and further compared with literature values (
). Moreover, X-ray diffraction experiments with CuKα (λ = 1.54178 Å) radiation allowed the absolute configurations of 7 to be assigned as 3 S , 7 S , 8 S , 9 R , 10 R , 13 R , 14 S , 17 R , 20 R . Furthermore, additional spectroscopic data of 7 (momordicoside K), including the IR and MS data are reported here.
2.2. Biological activity of cucurbitanes from the vine of M. charantia

The isolated cucurbitane-type triterpenoids ( 1–7 ) were evaluated for cytotoxicity against HEp-2 (laryngeal carcinoma), MCF-7 (breast adenocarcinoma), Hep-G2 (hepatocellular carcinoma), and WiDr (colon adenocarcinoma) human cancer cells and anti-inflammatory activity by the inhibition of LPS-stimulated NO production in RAW264.7 macrophage cells. Preliminary results of the cytotoxicity assay ( Table 3 ) showed that Kaguaovin K ( 4 ) exhibited moderate cytotoxicity with IC 50 values at 9.45 ± 0.51, 9.66 ± 0.34, 8.69 ± 0.46, and 9.23 ± 0.04 μM against MCF-7, HEp-2, Hep-G2, and WiDr cancer cells, respectively, whereas the activities of the other curcubitanes were weak (IC 50 values =20–40 μM) or inactive (IC 50 values > 40 μM). In the anti-inflammatory assay ( Table 4 ), all of the tested compounds showed potent anti-NO production with IC 50 values less than 20 μM. Among them, Kaguaovin K ( 4 ) exhibited remarkable inhibition of NO production with IC 50 7.40 ±0.27 at a concentration of 10 μg/mL. In the GLP-1 secretory assay, as shown in Fig. 4 A-C, GLP-1 secretory response by STC-1 cells was significantly elevated by compounds 1 , 3 , and 7 at the concentration up to 100 μg/mL. Compounds 1 and 3 have stronger GLP-1 secretory activity than 7 . Compound 1 appears to be more potent than rutin which has been shown to possess anti-diabetes effect via modulation of GLP-1 levels (
). Average EC 50 of compound 1 is 33 μg/mL.

sec.title: Orphanage
sec.p: a IC: Inhibitory concentration 50%.

sec.title: Orphanage
sec.p: 50 b (): > 40 μM. Positive control:mitomycin c, IC =0.36 ±0.03 μM (MCF-7), 50 0.42 ±0.03 μM (HEp-2), 0.51 ±0.03 μM (Hep-G2), and 0.42 ±0.03 μM (WiDr). All values are presented as the mean ± SD (n = 3). Cell lines: HEp-2: human laryngeal carcinoma; MCF-7: human breast adenocarcinoma; Hep-G2: human hepatocellular carcinoma; WiDr: human colon adenocarcinoma.

sec.title: 3. Conclusions
sec.p:
Seven cucurbitane-type triterpenoids, including six undescribed kaguaovins H-M ( 1–6 ), were successfully isolated by bioassay-directed fractionation from the 95% ethanol extract of the vine of wild
M. charantia
. The chemical structures of the undescribed cucurbitanes were determined by 1D and 2D NMR, as well as HRESIMS. Compounds 1–6 were evaluated for anti-NO production in LPS-stimulated RAW246.7 macrophage cells and cytotoxicity against four human cancer cell lines. Kaguaovin K ( 4 ) showed potent activity of both anti-NO production and cytotoxicity compared with the others, suggesting that the butenoic ester group at C- 3 in cucurbitane-type triterpenoids may obviously increase the bioactivities. Moreover, the 5 β ,19-epoxycucurbitane glycosides kaguaovins H ( 1 ) and J ( 3 ) increase GLP-1 secretory activities in STC-1 cells.

sec.title: 4.1. General
sec.p: The optical rotations were determined by using a JASCO P-2000 polarimeter. The infrared (IR) spectra were recorded on a Mattson Genesis II spectrometer (Thermo). Electrospray ionization mass spectrometry (ESIMS) data were obtained on an LCQ mass spectrometer (Thermo). High-resolution electronic ionization mass spectrometry (HREIMS) data were measured on a Shimadzu IT-TOF HR mass spectrometer. Nuclear magnetic resonance (NMR) spectra were recorded on Bruker Avance 400 MHz, Varian Unity Inova 500 MHz, and Varian VNMRS 600 MHz spectrometers. For column chromatography (CC), silica gel 60 (60–230 mesh, Merck) and Sephadex LH-20 (GE) were used. Precoated silica gel (Merck 60 F-254) plates were used for TLC. The spots on TLC were detected by spraying with an anisaldehyde-sulfuric acid (5% H 2 SO 4 ) solution and then heating at 110 ◦ C. MPLC was performed on a system equipped with a Büchi B-688 pump, Büchi B-684 fraction collector, and Büchi columns. HPLC separations were performed on a Shimadzu LC-8A pump with a UV SPD-20A detector equipped with a 250 × 20 mm i.d. preparative Cosmosil 5C 18 AR-II column (Nacalai Tesque). Solvents for general chromatography were RG grade except that those used for HPLC analysis were HPLC grade. Single-crystal X-ray diffraction measurements were carried out on a Bruker D8 VENTURE single-crystal XRD diffractometer equipped with an Oxford Cryostream 800 + .

sec.title: 4.2. Plant materials
sec.p:
The vines of wild
Momordica charnatia
L. ( Cucurbitaceae ), ( 9.5 kg , dry weight) were collected in the mountains of Maioli County , Taiwan , in
October 2010
and identified by Dr. Syh-Yuan Hwang of the Endemic Species Research Institute , Council of Agriculture , Taiwan (GPS 24 ◦ 66 ′ 18.1 ′′ N, 120 ◦ 73 ′ 74.3 ′′ E). A voucher specimen (No. NRICM20101001) has been deposited in the National Research Institute of Chinese Medicine , Ministry of Health and Welfare, Taipei, Taiwan.

sec.title: 4.3. Extraction and isolation
sec.p:
The air-dried vines of wild
M. charantia
( 9.5 kg ) were extracted three times with 95% ethanol (40 L) at 55 ◦ C, and the extracts were concentrated under reduced pressure (
). The ethanol extract ( ca. 2000 g ) was suspended in H 2 O, and the suspension was partitioned sequentially with n -hexane and CHCl 3 and then concentrated under reduced pressure to obtain hexane and CHCl 3 extracts. The CHCl 3 extract ( ca. 264 g ) was separated into 4 fractions (Fractions I ~ IV) on a silica gel flash column (60–230 mesh, 15 × 20 cm ) and eluted with a solvent system of CHCl 3 /MeOH (0–100%). Fraction III was further subjected to a Sephadex LH-20 column and eluted with 100% MeOH to afford three subfractions (IIIA-IIIC). IIIB was fractionated by preparative HPLC and eluted with 90% acetonitrile (ACN) in H 2 O (flow rate: 10.0 mL/min) to give 13 fractions (IIIB-1~IIIB-13). Fraction IIIB-6 was separated by HPLC and eluted with 71% ACN (flow rate: 8.0 mL/min) to afford seven fractions (IIIB-6-1~IIIB-6-7). IIIB-6-4 was further purified by recycling HPLC, eluting with 65% ACN (flow rate: 8.0 mL/min), to give compound 4 ( 4.1 mg , Rt: 24.2 min). Fraction IIIB-8 was separated by HPLC with 74% ACN (flow rate: 8.0 mL/min) to afford six fractions (IIIB-8-1~IIIB-8-6). IIIB-8-5 was purified by recycled HPLC, eluting with 65% ACN (flow rate: 8.0 mL/min) to give 1 ( 11.2 mg , Rt: 39.4 min) and 2 ( 4.9 mg , Rt: 40.3 min). Fraction IIIB-11 was separated by HPLC with 77% ACN (flow rate: 8.0 mL/min) to afford four fractions (IIIB-11-1~IIIB-11-4). IIIB-11-2 was further purified by HPLC, repeatedly eluting with 77% ACN (flow rate: 8.0 mL/min), to give 5 ( 5.1 mg , Rt: 21.4 min) and 3 ( 8.3 mg , Rt: 24.1 min). By HPLC eluting with 80% ACN (flow rate: 8.0 mL/min), fraction IIIB-13 was separated into two parts, IIIB-13-1 and IIIB-13-2, and the former was further purified by HPLC, eluting with 77% ACN (flow rate: 8.0 mL/min), to give compound 6 ( 2.9 mg , Rt: 30.1 min).

Kaguaovin H ( 1 ): white amorphous powder; [ α ] 25D -67 ( c 0.2, MeOH); IR (KBr) ν max 3440, 2953, 2876, 1752, 1732, 1642, 1446, 1377, 1279, 1148, 1111, 1074, 1025 cm 1 ; 1 H and 13 C-NMR spectroscopic data (pyridine- d 5 ) are shown in Tables 2 and 3 , respectively; HRESIMS m/z 771.4291 [M+Na] + (calcd. for C 41 H 64 O 12 Na + , 771.4295).

Kaguaovin I ( 2 ): white amorphous powder; [ α ] 25D -45 ( c 0.2, MeOH); IR (KBr) ν max 3399, 2946, 2876, 1754, 1728, 1640, 1446, 1373, 1336, 1262, 1148, 1107, 1021 cm 1 ; 1 H and 13 C-NMR spectroscopic data (pyridine- d 5 ) are shown in Tables 2 and 3 , respectively; HRESIMS m/z : 771.4284 [M+Na] + (calcd. for C 41 H 64 O 12 Na + , 771.4295).

Kaguaovin J ( 3 ): white amorphous powder; [α] 25D -69 ( c 0.2, MeOH); IR (KBr) ν max 3444, 2942, 2872, 1642, 1454, 1373, 1270, 1152, 1119, 1082, 1042 cm 1 ; 1 H and 13 C-NMR spectroscopic data ( pyridine-d 5 ) are shown in Tables 2 and 3 , respectively; HRESIMS m/z : 685.4283 [M+Na] + (calcd. for C 38 H 62 O 9 Na + , 685.4292).

Kaguaovin K ( 4 ): white amorphous powder; [ α ] 25D +52 ( c 0.2, MeOH); IR (KBr) ν max 3412, 2946, 2876, 1716, 1655, 1442, 1374, 1262, 1181, 1074, 1017 cm 1 ; 1 H and 13 C-NMR spectroscopic data ( pyridine-d 5 ) are shown in Tables 2 and 3 , respectively; HRESIMS m/z : 725.4228 [M+Na] + (calcd. for C 40 H 62 O 10 Na + , 725.4241).

Kaguaovin L ( 5 ): white amorphous powder; [ α ] 25D +35 ( c 0.2, MeOH); IR (KBr) ν max 3379, 2942, 2815, 1749, 1645, 1462, 1389, 1254, 1201, 1074 cm 1 ; 1 H and 13 C-NMR spectroscopic data (pyridine- d 5 ) are shown in Tables 2 and 3 , respectively; HRESIMS m/z : 701.4225 [M+Na] + (calcd. for C 38 H 62 O 10 Na + , 701.4241).
a Cells were treated with LPS (1 μg) or in combination with tested agents (10 μg/mL) for 24 h.
b IC: inhibitory concentration 50%. All values are presented as mean ± SD 50 (n =3). c Cell lines: RAW 264.7 mouse monocyte/macrophage. c Positive control: quercetin, IC 50 = 4.18 ± 0.12 μM.

Kaguaovin M ( 6 ): white amorphous powder; [ α ] 25D -93 ( c 0.2, MeOH); IR (KBr) ν max 3416, 2946, 2868, 1462, 1381, 1258, 1115, 1078, 1021 cm 1 ; 1 H and 13 C-NMR spectroscopic data (pyridine- d 5 ) are shown in Tables 2 and 3 , respectively; HRESIMS m/z : 525.3562 [M+Na] + (calcd for C 31 H 50 O 5 Na + , 525.3556).

Momordicoside K (7): colorless crystalline solid; mp 236–237 ◦ C; [ α ] 25D +52 ( c 0.4, MeOH) [Ref: +63.3 (
).]; IR (KBr) ν max 3437, 2942, 2874, 1713, 1449, 1380, 1113, 1081, 1049 cm 1 . ESIMS m/z : 649 [M+H] + .

sec.title: 4.4. Acid hydrolysis of compounds 1–5
sec.p:
Compounds 1–5 ( ca 1.0 mg) were each treated with 2N HCl in methanol (2 mL) and heated under reflux for 60 min. Each mixture was partitioned between CH 2 Cl 2 and H 2 O (1:1) to afford the CH 2 Cl 2 layer and H 2 O layer, and the latter layer was neutralized with Na 2 CO 3 and filtered. To the evaporated filtrates were added 1-(trimethylsilyl)imidazole and pyridine (0.2 mL), and then the mixture was heated at 60 ◦ C for 10 min. After the reaction mixture was dried under a stream of N 2 , each residue was partitioned between CH 2 Cl 2 and H 2 O. Each CH 2 Cl 2 extract was subjected to gas chromatography by using a CP-Chirasil- L - Val column, according to a previously reported method (
). The peaks of each hydrolysate from the isolated compounds were identified by comparison with the authentic sample (D-glucose, tR = 30.60 min).

sec.title: 4.5. X-ray crystallographic analysis of momordicoside K
sec.p:
The crystallographic data have been deposited in the Cambridge Crystallographic Data Centre (CCDC), and the CCDC deposition number is CCDC 1995317. Crystallographic data of 7 : A colorless crystal (0.20 ✕ 0.15 ✕ 0.10 mm 3 ) was obtained by simple evaporation from MeOH/H 2 O solution at room temperature. Crystal data: C 37 H 60 O 9 , orthorhombic, a = 10.1855 (2) Å, b = 7.5329 (12) Å, c = 24.0409 (5) Å, volume = 1842.79 (7) Å 3 , space group P21, Z =2, Dcalcd 1.169 Mg/m 3 , absorption coefficient 0.662 mm 1 , F (000) = 708.000. The X-ray intensity data were measured CuKα (λ = 1.54178 Å), T = 295 K. A total of 12,734 reflections were collected, of which 6658 independent reflections [ Rint = 0.0337] with
I >
2 σ (I) were used for the analysis. The data were solved using the direct method, and the structure was refined by a fullmatrix least-squares procedure on F2 values. All nonhydrogen atoms were refined with anisotropic thermal parameters. The hydrogen atom positions were idealized geometrically and allowed to ride on their parent atoms. The final indices were R1 0.0547 and wR2 0.1482 with the goodness of fit = 1.164. The X-ray data and ORTEP diagram are shown in the supplementary data.

sec.title: 4.6. Anti-NO production of the inflammatory activity
sec.p:
The macrophage cell line RAW 264.7 was obtained from ATCC (Rockville, MD), cultured in DMEM containing 5% heat-inactivated fetal calf serum, 100 U/mL penicillin and 100 μg/mL streptomycin and grown at 37 ◦ C with 5% CO
2 in
fully humidified air. Cells were plated at a density of 2 × 10 5 cells/well in 96-well culture plates and stimulated with LPS ( 1000 ng /mL) in the presence or absence of different concentrations of the tested compounds for 24 h simultaneously. All compounds were dissolved in DMSO and further diluted with sterile PBS. Nitrite (NO 2 ) accumulation in the medium was used as an indicator of NO production, which was measured by adding Griess reagent (1% sulfanilamide and 0.1% naphthylenediamine in 5% H 3 PO 4 ). NaNO 2 was used to generate a standard curve, and nitrite production was determined by measuring the optical density at 550 nm . All experiments were performed in triplicate. NO production by LPS stimulation was designated 100% for each experiment. Quercetin (Sigma, 98.0% HPLC) was employed as a positive control.

sec.title: 4.7. Cytotoxicity assay
sec.p: The cytotoxicity of the isolated cucurbitanes was tested against MCF-7, Hep-G2, HEp-2, and WiDr tumor cell lines by using the MTT [3-(4,5- dimethylthiazol-2-yl)-2,5-diphenyltetrazolium bromide] colorimetric method. The cell lines were cultured in minimum essential medium (MEM) supplemented with 10% fetal bovine serum, 100 unit/mL penicillin and 100 unit/mL streptomycin in 5% CO 2 and incubated at 37 ◦ C. Test samples and control drug standards were prepared at concentrations of 1, 4, 10, 20 and 40 μg/mL. After seeding 3 × 103 cells/well in a 96-well microplate for 4 h, 20 μL of sample or standard agent was placed in each well and incubated at 37 ◦ C for 3 days, and then 20 μL of MTT ( 2 mg /mL) was added for 4 h. After removal of the medium and addition of DMSO (200 μL/well) into the microplate with shaking for 10 min, the formazan crystals (the product of MTT reacting with dehydrogenase existing in mitochondria) were redissolved, and their absorbance was measured on a model MR 7000 microtiter plate reader (Dynatech International Corp., Edgewood, NY) at a wavelength of 550 nm . The IC 50 values of each compound were obtained from 50% inhibition of cell growth and were compared with the IC 50 value of the control.

sec.title: 4.8. GLP-1 secretion assay
sec.p: Murine intestinal secretin tumor cell line (STC-1) cells were used for GLP-1 secretion testing. The cells purchased from ATCC were routinely grown as a monolayer with DMEM containing a 10% fetal bovine serum and 5% penicillin and streptomycin mixture in culture dishes at 37 ◦ C under 5% CO 2 /air with 90% humidity. The cultured cells were seeded into 24-well plates (0.5 × 10 5 cells/well) and allowed to attach overnight. Then, the cells were washed with modified Krebs-Ringer biocarbonate buffer (KRBB, 1.1 mM glucose, and 0.1% BSA) three times and incubated for 30 min at 37 ◦ C. The wash buffer was then exchanged with test medium made with KRBB plus 16.7 mM glucose for 60 min at 37 ◦ C. The medium was then collected and stored at 20 ◦ C. Active GLP-1 levels in each sample were measured by a homogeneous time-resolved fluorescence assay (Cisbio, Codolet, France ) using a Cytation 5 Cell Imaging Multimode Reader (BioTek, VT, USA ).

sec.title: Declaration of competing interest
sec.p: The Authors declare no competing financial interests.

sec.title: Acknowledgments
sec.p: This work was supported by the Ministry of Science and Technology, Republic of China (MOST 104-2320-B-077-006-MY3 and MOST 107- 2320-B-077-003-MY3, 108-2811-B-077-500). The authors thank the members of the Y. H. Kuo Laboratory, who assisted and supported this study at the National Research Institute of Chinese Medicine, MOHW. The Instrument Center of National Taiwan Normal University is appreciated for HRESIMS and single-crystal X-ray diffraction measurements.

sec.title: Appendix A. Supplementary data
sec.p: Supplementary data to this article can be found online at https://doi. org/10.1016/j.phytochem.2021.113026.
